content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

Do you folks really think that this puzzle is (only) medium in difficulty?

It looks more like a hard one to me.
A bit tedious, but felt good to complete.

I'm really having trouble understanding the nuts and bolts here. I think I got the gist, though.

When I receive the seven depots as input, in what order are they? For the first puzzle, I get the lower left first, then the upper-right, then the left, then the lower-right, etc. I created a solution for that example, but for the next example, it seems that the depots must be coming in a different order? This gets really confusing; perhaps you can do this:

Number the depots top left = 0, top right = 1, left = 2, etc. and always pass the depots in order? So, always pass the sides of depot 0 first, then depot 1, then depot 2, etc.

If I'm understanding the puzzle correctly, this should be fine and will improve the comprehensibility of the puzzle greatly. If this defeats the point of the puzzle, then I obviously don't understand the point of the puzzle.

Cheers!

Interesting puzzle.

One issue: The last test case and last validator have more than 1 solution. Since the "alphabetically lowest character" appears more than once for the center depot, you may rotate one solution to get another solution.
Test case alternative solution: 4E 6A 1V 3C 5G 0U 2C
Validator alternative solution: 2F 0A 5X 3E 1J 6V 4T

Edits made:

I've rearranged and edited the texts.

I've also added the ASCII art illustrations, hoping that they will make it easier or more convenient for understanding the puzzles without opening the images separately (some may miss the image links).

If there's a way to show the images directly in the puzzle statement, just delete my illustrations.

(Unrelated note: wow, will somebody consider to create a puzzle with drawing the hexagons like that as the theme?)

What don't you understand? Also, open the image.

As mentioned in the input section, the depots are ordered by INDEX. Your task is to order them according to the rules, and the output should be ordered by POSITION.

I'll edit the input section to make that clearer. Thanks for your comment.

There's still the issue of non-unique solutions as mentioned in my earlier comment. I've thought about two approaches:

1. Remove the constraint of single solution and require the player to output all solutions instead.

2. Add a constraint that the "alphabetically lowest character may appear once only in every depot" and modify the test case and validator which violate this constraint.

What do you think? Any other ideas how to resolve that?

Judging the difficulty level of puzzles is sometimes more difficult than solving the puzzles themselves... I see this puzzle as a pathfinding puzzle where the rules define which nodes are linked.

In my opinion this puzzle may be classified as either Medium difficulty or Hard.
Please do! Ignore the objections, you have my permission

Another approach is to discard test cases with multiple solutions. Regenerate new test cases and find one that has a unique solution to fill-in.
I have not done a solution for this puzzle yet I do not know how a random pattern is more "difficult" than another random.
I think it's harder when there are more common textures among the depots, so more possible configurations need to be tested.

Oh. I've only solved it, and the first solution I generated was always the one the validator expected.

Let's expand...

Expand meaning outputting all solutions (after sorting)?

That's fine but I don't know how to revise the contributor's solution code. (My own solution is able to output all solutions.)

No no, I meant expanding my vision of the problem.

(bigger comment coming up)

Ok, reproduced the problem.

Indeed, the statement is inconsistent in its current state, as it allows multiple solutions yet states otherwise.

My code doesn't seem much slower on the later cases, though intuitively I agree more common textures should yield more combinatorial exploration, so that duplication ought to be kept.

So it's all a matter of resolving the ambiguity in the center piece's rotation.

I kinda dislike requiring to output all solutions, because that requires defining an order on them, and the most simple ones (lexicographical) don't make any sense in the problem domain.

My initial code resolved it (I assume like the problem author's code since we get the same results, though I don't really understand much of it) by taking the right wall as the lexicographically minimal starting point in the various depot rotations. I kinda dislike wording that up in a statement that's complex enough already.

So to bring it back to your initial answer, I wouldn't like to get down to option (2), I'd prefer some variation of (1). I've expressed two ways out. My implementation starts with the center, so it doesn't have any better incentive to output the lexicographically first solution only instead of the lexicographically sorted entire set, so those two (your 1 and my A) are equivalent in my view, difficulty-wise, but let's recognize they exist separately.

No strong opinions on which is the best, they're all warty in their own way.

Option 2 only restricts the appearance of the alphabetically lowest character in the same depot. There may still be multiple depots which have the same character which is alphabetically lowest for all of them, and there are absolutely no restrictions on the other characters.

True.

Would you be up to rewriting the last test/validator, with that constraint, keeping the same approximate level of difficulty?

I know I wouldn't. Well, ok, maybe I would, but I don't have *that* much available time right now.
I'll try and let you check ;)

Done. Revised two pairs of test cases/validators to enforce the new constraint:
* Assorted ring
* Random case, very hard

I could have revised the very hard puzzles to even harder (i.e. more configurations to be tested, at least if using my solution code), but the contributor's solution code fails such harder puzzles... (I did some tests. It seems that the code doesn't always test all the possibilities when a depot has duplicated letters.)

And approved.

My print-every-solution code passes again!

So... approved again.

Right, so the first one to come is "0" (which happens to be the lower-left one), the second is "1" (upper right), etc. right?

"Your task is to order them according to the rules" I assume you mean spin them about? I'm not allowed to move them around, right?

And the output is ordered by Position: I need to output 4, then 1, then 2, etc.

I did all that and it works for the first exercise (the example), but it's not working after that :-) I must still have something wrong; I look forward to seeing your edit.

Your goal is to find the positions which satisfy all the rules. The inputs give you all the depots ordered by index and tell you nothing about their positions.

So you can move the depots around, you can rotate the depots, but you can't flip them.
Edited the input and output further just now.
Thank you. It was not clear to me at all that I could move the depots. I'll give it another go.
OK, but note that this is an UNAPPROVED puzzle. It's not final/published yet.
Oh yeah, no sweat, dude! Happy to give it a pilot! Sorry if I seemed impatient or entitled. I'm trying to give useful feedback to make this an enjoyable puzzle for the community. Cheers!

OK as long as you understand that :)
And thanks for your contribution!

Please explain the output.
I think I got the gist

There is an output specification:

Line 1: The unique solution of seven pairs of two characters, a number of that of depot index and a letter. Out of the six possible orientations for the solution, print only the one for which the center hexagon is oriented with its alphabetically lowest character pointed to the right. The hexagon sequence must be printed left-to-right, top-to-bottom. The first hexagon in the input is the top left, and the last is the bottom right. After each index, the program must print the letter of the wall to the right. (see source for formatting-enhanced presentation)
Okay, and can the lines be arranged in clockwise and anticlockwise order?
Not sure what you mean, but I think hexagons can be rotated in whatever way you like, e.g. rotating once anticlockwise is just the same as rotating clockwise 5 times.
